ehpb4k7.Author: diydude2
ehpb4k7.Text:
Pretty interesting.  A couple of points:

1) Bitcoin to the S&P is not an apples-to-apples comparison.  There are -- as you know -- a lot of differences between the instruments and markets.  A better comparison might be to commodities where the price is heavily influenced by derivatives/futures and where it's a purely supply/demand play. Stocks move on all kinds of news and metrics related companies' performance.  You might be better off comparing with metals.

2) The Fed is *absolutely* propping up the stock market.  What are the implications?  Stocks could go "up" based on this free money, but is their *value* really going up?  What about the value of Bitcoin by comparison?  Is it likely to go up relative to fiat money that is being printed as though a bunch of sailors on three-day leave were in charge of the presses?

3) Liquidity.  Traditional TA is hit or miss with Bitcoin because the liquidity is so low.  One whale buying $200 million or shorting $200 million can cause a massive candle and blow any analysis out of the water.

3a) Take a look at the order books if you want to see where this is going.  It's about 7x as much money on the buy side as on the sell side.  I surmise that most of those buy orders in the $1000-2000 range have been placed by the guys that engineered the big dump back in November.  A LOT of Bitcoin was borrowed just prior to that dump (eg, 25,000 BTC from Genesis alone on November 12).  When will it be paid back?  That's when we bust out.

Trying to trade this is not smart in general.  Just buy dips and wait for for Shorty to pay his bills.

ehplb4t.Author: time_wasted504
ehplb4t.Text:
coinbase set that fee.

it would have gone through for 1sat/byte. (approx 168 sats = < 1 cent) but they charged you 11 cents

https://jochen-hoenicke.de/queue/#0,24h

edit: you can check on a block explorer what fee they actually paid. chuck your txid in here: https://www.smartbit.com.au/

ehpy5gd.Author: djulac
ehpy5gd.Text: Fee isn't a percentage of amount sent. You could've sent 1 million BTC for the same Miner's fee of 0.11$. It is mostly based on transaction size (in bytes).

ehpzqjm.Author: diydude2
ehpzqjm.Text:
Why would you transfer $2? Use Litecoin for that.

If you had transferred $20, the fee would have been the same, or .55%

If you had transferred $200, .055%

See how that works? Bitcoin isn't for sending $2, at least not on-chain.

ehpkxyu.Author: skebi
ehpkxyu.Text: Unfortunately yes. Mining fee is calculated on the transaction size. Sometimes a 2$ transaction has the same size of a 20$ transaction = same fee.

ehpbib8.Author: bitcoinfloridagator
ehpbib8.Text:
I think when the Fed prints trillions of dollars, that money finds it way into all asset markets including Bitcoin and if you notice, they seem to do it whenever the S&P is in jeapordy of going into a bear market which is why Powell went from saying on 10/3/18 that rates are a long way from neutral to magically going dovish towards Christmas which then propped the market higher.

The lack of credibility in the Fed is what ultimately will destroy the Dollar which is extremely bullish for Bitcoin and the two party system running up our debt just boxes the Fed more and more in a corner to be accommodative and keep rates near 0.

I am explaining the short term to people so they understand how a bottom is not necessarily a point in time but as a process that we’ve been playing out since 12/15/18. I’ve used this entire period to accumulate where I know in my heart of hearts Bitcoin will be a 6 digit and then a 7 digit number sometime in my life.

ehpdpqb.Author: diydude2
ehpdpqb.Text:
>  Bitcoin will be a 6 digit and then a 7 digit number

6 or 7 figures worth of dollars might not be much money in a few years.  1 BTC = 1 BTC.

Some of the money the Fed prints does find its way to Bitcoin indirectly, I'm sure.  People keep their jobs and keep buying Bitcoin.  A much higher percentage of that money goes more or less *directly* into propping up the stock market.

ehq1g5h.Author: diydude2
ehq1g5h.Text:
No.  It will not go down to fill those orders.  Those orders were placed by the same people who borrowed all that BTC (still not repaid) back in November to cause the big dump.  Those folks are sweating bullets now.  They can't hold that short forever, and they will be FORCED to cover at a loss.

TLDR: There's a lot more money on the buy side than on the sell side because certain people NEED to buy.
